history.content:
Industry cares far less about grades than grad school. If grad school doesnt care, industry probably cares even less. Even without the corona outbreak, P/NPing techs is fine. People outright fail multiple classes and can get in.

If any company asks for a transcript after making an offer, its usually to make sure you haven't lied If you get an offer, unless you lied egregiously about your gpa or taken classes, or you failed to graduate, they will not rescind your offer. Even if you took every "important" cs class p/NP or barely graduated with the 28 letter grad upper divs units needed, they won't rescind.

While most companies don't ask for transcripts as part of the new grad application process, I was wondering if for companies such as Google which do, it is looked down upon to take CS technicals P/NP? What if the CS technical is something useful in the context of industry, such as 162? What about companies that ask for transcripts after handing out an offer, would they raise eyebrows?

Asking because I'm straight up not having a good time in 162 and my MT1 performance showed that (and so will my MT2 performance in all likelihood given all the recent hullabaloo), and the new P/NP option is hella tempting.

(I already read @4949, but the responses were more oriented in the context of grad school, something I'm not considering pursuing.)
history.subject: Effect of P/NP on full-time applications + offers?
